abstract.text: Create a consistent UI animation experience across SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit.

inlineContent.text: Many apps use a combination of SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit to build and animate their interfaces.
In iOS 18 and later, you can use SwiftUI animations in UIKit and AppKit.
SwiftUI provides a wide range of standard as well as custom animation types.
SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit use different underlying implementations for animation.

Apps that use multiple frameworks for animation might encounter certain issues, such as syncing animation timing or other inconsistencies, that can be difficult to troubleshoot and lead to a suboptimal user experience.
Use SwiftUI animations to animate UI across all of these frameworks to create a more consistent and seamless experience on every platform.

type across SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit.

code: // Use a spring animation to animate the view to a new location.
let myView = UIView(frame: CGRect(origin: position, size: frame))
// Use a spring animation to animate the view to a new location.
let myView = NSView(frame: CGRect(origin: CGPoint(x: 50, y: 50),
let myButton = NSButton(title: "Animate", target: self, action: #selector(animateView))
// Use a spring animation to change the size of the view.

content.text: Use completion handlers with SwiftUI animations

inlineContent.text: You can provide an optional completion handler to these animation methods, which the system calls automatically after the animations complete.
The following examples show a completion handler that changes the background color of the view to indicate when the animation completes.

code: // Use a smooth spring animation to animate the view to a new location.
// When the animation completes, change the color of the view.
let myView = UIView(frame: CGRect(origin: position, size: frame))
// Use a smooth spring animation to animate the view to a new location.
// When the animation completes, change the color of the view.
let myView = NSView(frame: CGRect(origin: CGPoint(x: 50, y: 50),
let myButton = NSButton(title: "Animate", target: self, action: #selector(animateView))
// Use a smooth spring animation to change the size of the view.
// When the animation completes, change the color of the view.

Retargeting a SwiftUI animation uses the velocity from the previous animations to carry the animation forward with continuous velocity, creating a fluid animation experience.
The following examples show retargeting an in-progress animation.

code: // Begin an animation to move the view to a new location.
// Retarget the running animation to move the view to a different location.
let myView = UIView(frame: CGRect(origin: position, size: frame))
// Begin an animation to move the view to a new location.
// Retarget the running animation to move the view to a different location.
let myView = NSView(frame: CGRect(origin: CGPoint(x: 50, y: 50),
let myButton = NSButton(title: "Animate", target: self, action: #selector(animateView))
// Begin an animation to change the size of the view.
// Retarget the running animation to change the view to a different size.
